case_vignette:
A 72-year-old man presents to the clinic with an intensely itchy rash on his abdomen and chest that appeared 2 months prior. He denies starting any new medications prior to the onset of the eruption and any systemic symptoms. Although he traveled and stayed in hotels recently, he reports that his wife does not exhibit any similar symptoms. Physical examination reveals numerous discrete papules, crusted papules, and papulovesicles on the chest, abdomen, and mid-back. His upper and lower extremities, face, and groin are unaffected. The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a history of smoking. The patient is a retired accountant and has a family history of skin cancer. The patient's wife is a 68-year-old woman who has a history of breast cancer and hypertension.

I have an intensely itchy rash on my abdomen and chest that started 2 months ago.
Have you noticed any changes or triggers that seem to worsen the rash?

Final Diagnosis: Cutaneous T-cell Lymphoma (CTCL)
